tenant.description: The unique identifier for the tenant.

principal_name.description: The friendly name of the user associated with the activity, if available, otherwise the email address or API key.

object_id.description: The identifier for the object against which the action occurred.

happened_at.description: The date and time at which the action occurred. Dates and times are in ISO-8601 format and in UTC.

tenant_family.description: The unique identifier for the tenant family

object_name.description: A composed string that describes the object(s) for which the action occurred.

principal_email.description: The email address for the user who initiated the action.

principal_id.description: The identifier for the user who initiated the action. This user may be an API key or a non-human user.

origin_ip.description: The IP address that is associated with the user who initiated the action.

event_id.description: The unique identifier for the event.

total.description: The total count of all results. This property is only returned when `with_total` is set to `true` in a request.

next_token.description: The cursor value to use in a subsequent request to return the next page of results.

deliver_at.description: The instant this campaign should be delivered

total.description: The total count of all results. This property is only returned when `with_total` is set to `true` in a request.

next_token.description: The cursor value to use in a subsequent request to return the next page of results.

total.description: The total count of all results. This property is only returned when `with_total` is set to `true` in a request.

next_token.description: The cursor value to use in a subsequent request to return the next page of results.

tenant.description: The unique identifier for the tenant.

timeout_ms.description: The length of time in milliseconds after which to forcibly kill a running task instance

run_id.description:
Unique identifier for the task instance to support execution engines
   that can't provide an external run id

task_definition_type.description: A keyword for identify different task types

ended_at.description: Time the task reached a terminal state

execution_type.description: The execution type for the workflow.

state_changed_at.description: Time the task instance most recently changed state

task_instance_id.description: Unique identifier for the task instance

created_at.description: Time the task instance was created

tenant.description: The unique identifier for the tenant.

warn_after_ms.description: The time in milliseconds we should send a running long duration warning

principal_name.description: Human-readable name for who or what created the workflow

launched_version.description: The ent version that was launched with the workflow

principal_email.description: Email address for who or what created the workflow

principal_id.description: Principal id for who or what created the workflow

type.description: Keyword identifying the type of workflow

current_version.description: The current ent version associated with the workflow

ended_at.description: Time the workflow reached a terminal state

data.description: Any data associated with the error.

attribution.description: The underlying cause of the error, either customer or platform

total.description: The total count of all results. This property is only returned when `with_total` is set to `true` in a request.

next_token.description: The cursor value to use in a subsequent request to return the next page of results.

parameters.name: with_total
parameters.description: Set this value to `true` to include a total count of all results. Default value: `false`. Obtaining the total count of all results can be an expensive operation when there is a high number of pages in the results set.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: The maximum number of records to include in a single page of results.

parameters.name: api_version
parameters.description: A supported version of the Amperity API. You may use the `api-version` request header instead of the `api-version` request parameter.

parameters.name: next_token
parameters.description: An opaque token that is used to paginate results. Omit the `next_token` property to return the first page. Use the cursor value for `next_token` that was returned in a response to view the next page of results.

parameters.name: happened_from
parameters.description: The start date (inclusive) that defines the beginning of the time range for which audit events will be returned. The date should be in ISO-8601 format and in UTC.

parameters.name: happened_to
parameters.description: The end date (exclusive) that defines the end of the time range for which audit events will be returned. The date should be in ISO-8601 format and in UTC.

get.description: Use the Audit Events endpoint to return a log of user activity that occurred with your tenant. When requesting events for a production tenant, all events (including events from sandboxes created for that tenant) are included in the response. When requesting events from a sandbox, only events from that sandbox are included in the response.

parameters.name: with_total
parameters.description: Set this value to `true` to include a total count of all results. Default value: `false`. Obtaining the total count of all results can be an expensive operation when there is a high number of pages in the results set.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: The maximum number of records to include in a single page of results.

parameters.name: api_version
parameters.description: A supported version of the Amperity API. You may use the `api-version` request header instead of the `api-version` request parameter.

parameters.name: next_token
parameters.description: An opaque token that is used to paginate results. Omit the `next_token` property to return the first page. Use the cursor value for `next_token` that was returned in a response to view the next page of results.

parameters.name: destination_data_template_id
parameters.description: Use this parameter to restrict the list of campaigns that are returned to only campaigns that are configured to use specific data template.

parameters.name: with_total
parameters.description: Set this value to `true` to include a total count of all results. Default value: `false`. Obtaining the total count of all results can be an expensive operation when there is a high number of pages in the results set.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: The maximum number of records to include in a single page of results.

parameters.name: api_version
parameters.description: A supported version of the Amperity API. You may use the `api-version` request header instead of the `api-version` request parameter.

parameters.name: next_token
parameters.description: An opaque token that is used to paginate results. Omit the `next_token` property to return the first page. Use the cursor value for `next_token` that was returned in a response to view the next page of results.

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: Filters for workflow objects having a type field that matches this value

parameters.name: next_token
parameters.description: An opaque token that is used to paginate results. Omit the `next_token` property to return the first page. Use the cursor value for `next_token` that was returned in a response to view the next page of results.

parameters.name: state
parameters.description: Filters for workflow objects having a state field that matches this value

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: The maximum number of records to include in a single page of results.

parameters.name: ended_from
parameters.description: Timestamp, in ISO-8601 format and UTC, representing the beginning (inclusive) of a time interval in which to filter workflows on ended_at field. Workflows without an ended_at field will not be returned.

parameters.name: created_from
parameters.description: Timestamp, in ISO-8601 format and UTC, representing the beginning (inclusive) of a time interval in which to filter workflows on created_at field.

parameters.name: api_version
parameters.description: A supported version of the Amperity API. You may use the `api-version` request header instead of the `api-version` request parameter.

parameters.name: ended_to
parameters.description: Timestamp, in ISO-8601 format and UTC, representing the end (exclusive) of a time interval in which to filter workflows on ended_at field. Workflows without an ended_at field will not be returned.

parameters.name: created_to
parameters.description: Timestamp, in ISO-8601 format and UTC, representing the end (exclusive) of a time interval in which to filter workflows on created_at field.

parameters.name: with_total
parameters.description: Set this value to `true` to include a total count of all results. Default value: `false`. Obtaining the total count of all results can be an expensive operation when there is a high number of pages in the results set.

parameters.name: view
parameters.description: Get the standard workflow ("overview", by default) or the full verbose workflow with launched tasks included ("verbose").

parameters.name: api_version
parameters.description: A supported version of the Amperity API. You may use the `api-version` request header instead of the `api-version` request parameter.

info.title: Amperity API
info.description:
# Overview

## Who is this for?

This documentation is for developers creating their own integration with [Amperity](https://docs.amperity.com/reference/api/) APIs.


## Authentication

API calls must be authenticated with an [API Key](https://docs.amperity.com/reference/api/).


## Service URL

The base service URL follows the pattern `https://<tenant-id>.amperity.com/api`, for example:

```sh
> curl https://acme.amperity.com/api/campaigns?limit=2 \\
  -H \"Authorization: Bearer <token>\" \\
  -H \"Amperity-Tenant: acme\" \\
  -H \"api-version: 2024-04-01\"
```

When working with a [sandbox tenant](https://docs.amperity.com/datagrid/sandboxes.html),
use the parent tenant in the URL and the sandbox tenant id in the `Amperity-Tenant` header:

```sh
> curl https://acme.amperity.com/api/campaigns?limit=2 \\
  -H \"Authorization: Bearer <token>\" \\
  -H \"Amperity-Tenant: acme-sb-2zezitlj\" \\
  -H \"api-version: 2024-04-01\"
```


## Headers

Common headers used in Amperity APIs:

- `Authorization`: *(required)* The bearer authentication header, typically an API Key
- `api-version`: *(required)* The version of the API to use, e.g. `2024-04-01`.  See [Versioning](#section/Overview/Versioning) for more information. This can also be provided as a query parameter, but the value provided in the header will be used over any query parameter in event of conflicting values.
- `Amperity-Tenant`: *(required)* The tenant id or sandbox tenant id for the request, e.g. `acme2`


## Pagination

Amperity APIs implement standard cursor based pagination scheme for all `GET` resource collections.
When you send a request to an endpoint that supports pagination, the response body returns the
first page of results. When there are no more results, the `next_token` will not be present.
To iterate through a collection, use the following URL query parameters:

- `with_total`: when true, include a total count of all results. Obtaining the record count may slow down API response time. Defaults to false.
- `next_token`: opaque token used to paginate through results.  Omit the `next_token` parameter to get the first page of results.
- `limit`: The maximum number of records to include in a single page of results. The endpoint may decide to return fewer results than the caller asked for, even if there is more data available.

The response object will include the following fields:

- `data`: JSON array of values in the current page of results.
- `next_token`: The cursor value to use in a subsequent request to fetch the next page of results.  When there are no more results, the `next_token` will not be included in the response.  If an endpoint returns a full listing it will have the same response shape as one that paginates but has no more results.
- `total`: When requested with `with_total`, the total number of records.


## Error Response

For requests that result in errors, a standard error response shape will be returned with the fields:

- `status`: The status code of the error
- `message`: A human readable error message
- `request_id`: An optional Amperity request id
- `trace_id`: An optional Amperity trace id for use in tracing

Example:
```json
{\"status\": 400,
 \"message\": \"Error updating database: Can't rename to existing database table 'Customized_UIT'\",
 \"request_id\":\"6ce22158-e79a-4968-8898-35dbe4eb90e1\",
 \"trace_id\":\"1c9d3727772ac1af0f590aeeeda1aded\"}
```
 
## Versioning

Versioning is controlled by a `api-version` header, which is a date in `YYYY-MM-DD` format that
represents the \"version\" of the API which you expect from Amperity. It is designed to give
developers the freedom to adapt to Amperity API changes on their own schedule. 

All API requests *require* a version parameter; we will not default you to the latest version.
This gives developers control over the time period in which to call our continuously updated API.
If you do not include an version in the request, an error will be returned. In order to stay up
to date with the latest changes, Amperity recommends updating your version as often as possible.
Using a single version across all API calls will avoid any incompatibilities between APIs.


### Supported Versions

The currently supported versions are:
* `2024-04-01`


### Unstable

During development, Amperity may release APIs for testing using the `unstable` version identifier.
Unstable versions contain features that are still in progress and may not be backward compatible.
There are no guarantees around customer support, notification of changes, breaking changes, or
availability of unreleased versions.


### Lifespan

Amperity will periodically release new versions throughout the year and each version will be
supported for at least 1 year.  Amperity will provide at least 6 months notice before marking
a version as unsupported. API calls made with a version identifier that is no longer supported
will error with a 400 response.  Developers should monitor our API documentation to know when
versions are no longer supported.


### Deprecation

As Amperity continues to grow and evolve, we will occasionally deprecate fields or entire endpoints.
Fields or parameters being deprecated will be annotated as such in the documentation. To warn
developers of impending deprecation for an endpoint, a `Deprecation` header will be included and a
`Sunset` header may be included.  The `Deprecation` header will either be `true` to indicate an
endpoint has been deprecated or a future date as described in the
[Deprecation Header proposal](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-httpapi-deprecation-header).
In addition, a [Sunset header](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8594) may be included to
indicate the date at which the endpoint may cease to function and return a 4xx response.

The `Deprecation` and `Sunset` headers will be added 6 months prior to an endpoint's removal.  The
value of the `Deprecation` header will be 3 months before the endpoint's removal date.  The value
of the `Sunset` header is the removal date.

The purpose of the `Deprecation` and `Sunset` headers is merely informational.  We recommend clients
build alerts on this monitoring information to ensure the proper amount of time for migration. Example:

```
Deprecation: Tue, 1 Sep 2024 23:59:59 GMT
Sunset: Wed, 1 Dec 2024 23:59:59 GMT
```


### Breaking Changes

Any breaking changes will be released in a new API version.  A breaking change is any change
that requires a third-party developer to do any migration work to maintain the existing
functionality of their application. Some examples of breaking changes are:

* adding pagination to a resource collection response
* adding a new or modifying an existing validation to an existing resource
* requiring a parameter that wasnâ€™t required before
* changing existing error response codes/messages
* changing the data type of an existing field
* changing supported filtering on existing endpoints
* removing an endpoint
* removing or renaming a parameter or response field
* removing an enum value
* adding a new feature that will change the meaning of a field
* changing the URL structure of an existing endpoint

Additive changes are non-breaking:
* adding an endpoint
* adding an optional parameter
* adding an optional request header
* adding a response field or header
* adding an enum value
